basics.name: Namit Shrivastava
basics.summary: Ph.D. student in Measurement, Statistics, and Evaluation at the University of Maryland, College Park. Research focuses on causal inference, psychometrics, and computational methods in educational and health data.

work.summary: Conducting research on causal inference methods and psychometric modeling under Dr. Gregory Hancock.
highlights: Developing novel statistical methods for causal inference in educational data
Applying structural equation modeling to complex research designs
Contributing to methodological research on measurement and evaluation

work.summary: Teaching assistant for graduate-level statistics and measurement courses.
highlights: Supporting instruction in advanced statistical methods
Providing individualized support to graduate students

work.summary: Conducted research on automated scoring and natural language processing applications in educational assessment.
highlights: Developed machine learning models for automated essay scoring
Collaborated with senior researchers on psychometric validation studies

work.summary: Worked on computational statistics and machine learning projects in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics.
highlights: Implemented statistical learning algorithms for high-dimensional data
Conducted simulation studies for method validation
Published research findings in peer-reviewed journals

education.area: Ph.D. in Measurement, Statistics, and Evaluation

publications.name: Causal Inference Methods in Educational Research
publications.summary: A comprehensive review of causal inference methods applicable to educational data, including propensity score methods, instrumental variables, and regression discontinuity designs.

publications.name: Psychometric Properties of Assessment Instruments
publications.summary: Investigation of the psychometric properties of educational assessment instruments using item response theory and factor analysis.

publications.name: Statistical Computing Methods for Large-Scale Data
publications.summary: Development and evaluation of efficient computational methods for analyzing large-scale educational and health data.

presentations.name: Advances in Causal Inference for Educational Research
presentations.event: American Educational Research Association (AERA) Annual Meeting
presentations.description: Presented novel methods for causal inference in educational settings with complex data structures.

presentations.name: Item Response Theory Applications in Assessment
presentations.event: National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME) Annual Meeting
presentations.description: Demonstrated practical applications of IRT in educational assessment development and validation.

presentations.name: Machine Learning in Educational Data Mining
presentations.event: International Conference on Educational Data Mining
presentations.description: Explored machine learning techniques for pattern discovery in educational data.

teaching.description: Assisted with instruction in regression analysis, ANOVA, and multivariate methods.
Supported teaching of classical test theory, reliability, and validity concepts.

portfolio.name: Weather Guardian: Automated Daily Weather Briefing System
portfolio.description: Built an intelligent workflow using n8n, OpenWeatherMap API, and Supabase to automatically generate and email daily weather briefings. Features include weather data collection, JavaScript-based condition classification, PostgreSQL storage for historical analysis, and HTML email generation with contextual recommendations.

portfolio.name: Causal Inference Toolkit in R
portfolio.description: Developed an R package implementing various causal inference methods including propensity score matching, inverse probability weighting, and doubly robust estimation.

portfolio.name: IRT Simulation Study Framework
portfolio.description: Created a comprehensive simulation framework for evaluating item response theory models under various conditions.
